name: Sankore Mosque & University
description: Historic 15th-century mosque and former university, one of the oldest institutions of higher learning in Africa. This UNESCO World Heritage site was once the intellectual heart of the Islamic world.

name: Djinguereber Mosque
description: Built in 1327, this is one of the oldest and most famous mosques in Africa. Its distinctive Sudano-Sahelian architectural style with protruding wooden beams makes it an iconic symbol of Timbuktu.

name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
description: Dating from around 1400, this mosque is said to have a door that will only open at the end of the world. It represents the spiritual heritage and mystique that surrounds Timbuktu.

name: Ahmed Baba Institute
description: A modern library and research center dedicated to preserving Timbuktu's ancient manuscripts. It houses thousands of historical documents that showcase the city's scholarly traditions.

name: Timbuktu Market Square
description: The vibrant heart of modern Timbuktu where traditional goods, crafts, and spices are traded. This bustling market continues the city's 1000-year-old tradition as a trading hub.

name: Niger River Port
description: The historic port that connected Timbuktu to the world. Located 8km from the city center, this is where salt, gold, and knowledge once flowed through ancient trade routes.

name: Ethnological Museum
description: Showcasing the rich cultural heritage of the Songhai, Tuareg, and other ethnic groups that have shaped Timbuktu's identity over centuries. Features traditional crafts, weapons, and artifacts.

name: Desert Dunes Gateway
description: The edge of the Sahara Desert where golden sand dunes meet the ancient city. A breathtaking landscape that has inspired travelers, traders, and scholars for over a millennium.
